Wow, sounds cool.

If you can reimplement the FindClusterExperiment or do s=
omething similar with the HyperNEAT source and CUDA, please let me know and=
 send me the code so I can incorporate it into the HyperNEAT source.  I thi=
nk this would be of great benefit to the entire community.

--- In neat@yah=
oogroups.com, "Nikolai" <ker_31_toluca@...> wrote:
>
> neither i am an expe=
rt in GPU programming. I use CUDA and it maps it pretty well, you even don'=
t have to know what a texture is. Just knowing the basic architecture of th=
e card is enough. I have ran some activation tests, and a simple kernel to =
activate 13,107,200 nodes with 7 incoming links each takes 20 milliseconds =
(with sigmoid exp-based function, step function would do much faster). This=
 is on one GPU , but you can have 4 , and even 7 in a motherboard. All conn=
ected with a PCI bus transfering at 2.5Gbytes per sec, against traditional =
single core cluster on obsolete GigaBit ethernet which is only 100MB per se=
c. With 4 NVIDIA GTX295 cards you can have a supercomputer with 1920 cores =
for about 4,000-5,000USD. But the key for fast implementation is, of course=
, knowing your hardware, so , for example to count bits in an integer you d=
on't use ANDs and ORs, but special assembly language instructions like POPC=
NT, MMX instructions with non-polluting cache loads like _mm_stream_si128()=
 which can speed up your software hundreds of times. I think the only reaso=
n we don't have an artificial brain yet is because we don't have enough cor=
es to do the math, but for the methods invented, we already surpassed all t=
he possible algorithms we would need. So, it is all about computing power n=
ow.
>
